revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox Newspaper | name = Algemeen Handelsblad | image = AlgemeenHandelsblad.JPG | caption = Paleisstraat (Amsterdam) | type = [[Daily newspaper]] | format = | foundation = 1828 | ceased publication = 1 October 1970 | owners = [[Nederlandse Dagbladunie]] (1962–1970) | publisher = | editor = | chiefeditor = | assoceditor = | staff = | language = [[Dutch language|Dutch]] | political = [[Liberalism|Liberal]] | circulation = | headquarters = [[Amsterdam]] | oclc = | ISSN = | website = }} [[File:Jan van Dijk Algemeen Handelsblad -Bedrijfsfotografie 1940 p 297.jpg|thumb|left|People reading ''Algemeen Handelsblad'']] '''''Algemeen Handelsblad''''' was an influential [[Amsterdam]]-based [[Liberalism|liberal]] daily [[newspaper]] published between 1828 and 1970.
==History and profile== ''Algemeen Handelsblad'' was founded in 1828<ref name=cordula>{{cite book|author=Cordula Rooijendijk|title=That City is Mine!: Urban Ideal Images in Public Debates and City Plans, Amsterdam & Rotterdam 1945-1995|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pW9ZAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA23|accessdate=9 December 2014|year=2005|publisher=Amsterdam University Press|isbn=978-90-5629-382-6|page=23}}</ref> by [[J.W. van den Biesen]], a [[stock broker]].<ref name=amst>{{cite web|title=Algemeen Handelsblad Newspaper|url=http://www.amsterdamtourism.net/algemeen_handelsblad.html|publisher=Amsterdam Tourism|accessdate=19 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150119192349/http://www.amsterdamtourism.net/algemeen_handelsblad.html|archivedate=19 January 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The paper aimed at providing news about [[trade]], [[Share (finance)|share holding]] and [[banking]].<ref name=amst/> Later its coverage was expanded to cover political news.<ref name=amst/>
At the peak of its influence—from the time of the [[Boer War]], when it championed the [[Boer]] cause in [[South Africa]], through [[World War I]] -- it was edited by [[Charles Boissevain]]. The paper had a [[Liberalism in the Netherlands|liberal]] stance.<ref name=cordula/>
''Algemeen Handelsblad'' merged in 1970 with the [[Rotterdam]]-based liberal daily newspaper ''[[Nieuwe Rotterdamsche Courant]]'' into the ''[[NRC Handelsblad]]''.<ref name=cordula/><ref>{{cite web|title=NRC Handelsblad|url=http://www.eurotopics.net/en/home/medienindex/media_articles/?frommedia=241|publisher=Euro Topics|accessdate=19 January 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:1828 establishments in the Netherlands]] [[Category:1970 disestablishments in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Publications established in 1828]] [[Category:Publications disestablished in 1970]] [[Category:Defunct newspapers of the Netherlands]] [[Category:Dutch-language newspapers]] [[Category:Media in Amsterdam]] [[Category:Daily newspapers published in the Netherlands]]
{{netherlands-newspaper-stub}}

page.title: Biblioteca europea di informazione e cultura

revision.text:
The '''Biblioteca Europea di Informazione e Cultura''' ('''BEIC''', "European library of information and culture") is an ongoing project based in [[Milan]], [[Italy]] for the realization of a new modern [[library]]. It began in the late nineties, when [[Antonio Padoa-Schioppa]] submitted the idea for the first time to the City of Milan and the [[Italian Ministry of Cultural Heritage and Activities|Italian Ministry of Cultural Heritage and Activities and Tourism]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beic.it/it/articoli/genesi-e-sviluppi-del-progetto-1996-2011|title=Genesi e sviluppi del progetto (1996-2011) - www.beic.it|publisher=}}</ref> The library will be split in two main units: physical and virtual.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beic.it/it/articoli/il-sistema-beic|title=Il sistema BEIC - www.beic.it|publisher=}}</ref>
== BeicDL == The BEIC digital library (BeicDL) inauguration took place on 30 November 2012<ref>http://www.beic.it/it/content/presentazione-beic-30-novembre-2012</ref> and it has more than 27.000 digital objects and 3.000 authors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beic.it/en/articles/digital-library|title=Digital Library |website=beic.it |publisher=}}</ref> The items are articulated in semantic collections and are freely accessible through the web.<ref>http://ermes.beic.it:1701/primo_library/libweb/action/search.do?vid=BEIC</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Leva |first1=Federico |last2=Chemello |first2=Marco |date=2018 |title=The effectiveness of a Wikimedian in permanent residence: the BEIC case study |url=https://www.jlis.it/article/view/12481 |journal=JLIS.it |volume=9 |issue=3 |pages= |doi=10.4403/jlis.it-12481 |access-date=17 September 2018 }}</ref>
== Archive of the Regional legal deposit of Lombardy == According to Italian Law 106 of April 15, 2004 all the Italian Region must collect all the items submitted for legal deposit. [[Lombardy]] Region has entrusted the management of its Archive of Published Documents to BEIC, with the support of the [[Biblioteca di Brera|Biblioteca Nazionale Braidense]] of Milan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beic.it/en/articles/legal-deposit|title=Legal Deposit |website=beic.it |publisher=}}</ref> The Archive has its own Opac. <ref>http://ermes.beic.it:1701/primo_library/libweb/action/search.do?vid=APE</ref>
== Paolo Monti Archive == In 2008 BEIC acquired the whole [[Paolo Monti]] Archive, declared of notable historical interest by the Italian [[Ministry of Cultural Heritage and Activities and Tourism (Italy)|Ministry of Cultural Heritage and Activities]]. The Archive - counting more than 223.000 negatives, 12.244 prints, and 790 [[chemigram]]s - has been catalogued and opened to the public.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.beic.it/mostre/monti/archivio.html|title=Archivio Paolo Monti|website=Beic.it|access-date=2016-10-27|language=it}}</ref><ref name="diz">{{cite web|url=http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/paolo-monti_%28Dizionario_Biografico%29/|title=Monti, Paolo|work=Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani|publisher=Treccani|language=Italian|accessdate=2016-10-27}}</ref>
==References== <references />
{{coord|45.4649|N|9.1892|E|source:wikidata|display=title}}
[[Category:Digital libraries]] [[Category:Libraries in Milan]]
{{italy-stub}}

| logo = | logosize = | logolink = | logoalt = }} The '''Chapel of St Michael''' more popularly known in [[Maltese language|Maltese]] as '''Il-Kappella tas-San Ċir''' or '''Il-Kappella ta' San Mikiel is Sanċir''' is a medieval chapel located in the limits of [[Rabat, Malta]] in an area referred to as ''Ġnien is-Sultan'' (King's Garden).
==Origins== The chapel's architecture dates back to the middle of the [[15th century]]. The first mention of the chapel is found in a report written by Bishop Pietro Dusino when he visited Malta in 1575. The report refers to the church as the church of St Michael in the garden of ''Ġnien is-Sultan''. The chapel was mentioned numerous times through the years, notably in 1615 when Bishop [[Baldassare Cagliares]] described the painting of St Michael located in the church as barely recognizable, indicating the poor state of the chapel. In 1598 Bishop Gargallo mentions that the feast of St Michael was celebrated every September 29 with vespers, which were attended by the local farmers. Due to its neglected state, in 1678 Bishop [[Miguel Jerónimo de Molina]] deconsecrated the church and ordered that the painting of St Michael be transferred to the parish church of Rabat.<ref>Spiteri, Mikiel (2000). ''A Hundred Wayside Chapels of Malta & Gozo'', pp. 60-61. Heritage Books, Valletta. {{ISBN|999099305X}}.</ref> [[File:Interior_of_San_Mikiel_is-Sancier.jpg|230px|thumb|left|Interior of the chapel]]
==Use as a stable== After the chapel fell in disrepair it was used as a stable and storage space by local farmers. A wall was built inside the chapel to divide it in two sections.
==Restoration== In 1981 the chapel was restored and the wall that divided the chapel was demolished. The chapel was restored by volunteers from the Sanċir Trust and volunteers from the National Students Travel Foundation and the Friends of Malta. A stone altar was built and the church was reopened for religious services on October 2, 1988. The [[President of Malta]], [[Ugo Mifsud Bonnici]] attended the opening service. The service was led by Monsignor Gwann Azzopardi who was a benefactor of the chapel's restoration.
==Present day== In the 30 years since the church was restored, it has fallen into disuse and disrepair and is in danger of collapsing. Vegetation has grown on the walls of the chapel and trees have blocked the main entrance of the chapel. Part of the roof near the altar has collapsed, and cracks in the chapel's walls are visible.<ref>[http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20130512/local/chapel.469441 "NGO calls for rehabilitation of chapel"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160919000539/http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20130512/local/chapel.469441 |date=2016-09-19 }}, ''[[Times of Malta]]'', Malta, 12 May 2014. Retrieved on 18 September 2016.</ref><ref>Grech, Alfred. [http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20121001/letters/Save-Ta-San-ir-chapel.439125 "Save Ta’ Sanċir chapel"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160919072151/http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20121001/letters/Save-Ta-San-ir-chapel.439125 |date=2016-09-19 }}, ''[[Times of Malta]]'', Malta, 1 October 2012. Retrieved on 18 September 2016.</ref>
==Interior== The interior of the chapel is quite bare. The interior is one spacious room with the walls built in the form of pointed arches, typical to medieval architecture in Malta. There is one stone altar. During the restoration of the 1980s, stone benches were discovered along the wall of the chapel. The chapel can be accessed by two doors. A [[Graffiti]] of a ship, which was discovered on the walls of the chapel, is probably some kind of [[Ex-voto]].
==Name of the chapel== The chapel's origins may date to the Byzantine era, as evidenced by the chapel's name, ''Is-Sanċir''. According to Professor Stanley Fiorini, the name ''is-Sanċir'' may indicate that the chapel was dedicated to [[Cyriacus the Anchorite]], a Greek saint. After the Moors were driven out of Malta, Christianity regained its power over Malta. Western Latin Christianity was spreading, replacing any traces of the Greek Christianity in Malta,which dated from Byzantine times. As a result, the names of churches in Malta which had been dedicated to Greek saints were replaced by the names of popular Western saints. Thus, the name of this chapel might have been changed from St Cyriacus (''San Ċirijaku'' or ''San Ċir'' in Maltese) to St Michael (''San Mikiel''). It is possible that the local people referred to the chapel by its original name, hence the name ''San Mikiel Is-Sanċir'' or literal translation in English, St Michael the St Cyr. However, no documentation survives to prove this theory.<ref>Ciantar, Noel. [http://www.ciantar.org/kappellimaltin/Il-Kappelli/Sett07/RBT_Mik_Sancir/rbt_mik_sancir.html "Il-Knisja ta’ San Mikiel Is-Sanċir ~ Rabat ~"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160919075235/http://www.ciantar.org/kappellimaltin/Il-Kappelli/Sett07/RBT_Mik_Sancir/rbt_mik_sancir.html |date=2016-09-19 }}, ''Kappelli Maltin'', Malta. Retrieved on 18 September 2016.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
The '''Commission on Global Governance''' was an organization co-chaired by [[Sweden|Swedish]] Prime Minister [[Ingvar Carlsson]], and former [[Commonwealth Secretary-General]] [[Shridath Ramphal]], that produced a controversial report, ''[[Our Global Neighborhood]]'', in 1995.<ref>[https://www.un.org/documents/ga/conf166/ngo/950307140407.htm SPEECH BY MINISTER JAN PRONK AT THE WORLD SUMMIT FOR SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT]</ref> The report was attacked by pro-[[sovereignty]] groups for calling for [[United Nations]] reforms that would increase its power. It also was criticized by [[world government|world federalist]]s who disliked the terminology of "[[global governance]]", which seemed clunkier than "world federalism."
The Commission was established in 1992 with the full support of [[United Nations Secretary-General]] [[Boutros Boutros-Ghali]].
The Commission made a standard definition of [[global governance]] stating that “Governance is the sum of many ways individuals and institutions, public and private, manage their common affairs. It is a continuing process through which conflicting or diverse interests may be accommodated and co-operative action taken. It includes formal institutions and regimes empowered to enforce compliance, as well as informal arrangements that people and institutions either have agreed to or perceive to be in their interest”<ref>The Commission on Global Governance, ''Our Global Neighbourhood'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1995, p. 4.</ref>
==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121019090306/http://www.sovereignty.net/p/gov/gganalysis.htm Sovereignty International - Analysis and Report]. *The Commission on Global Governance, ''Our Global Neighbourhood'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1995.
==Notes== <references/>
[[Category:Global policy organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established by the United Nations]] [[Category:International commissions|Global Governance]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = Dolu | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | director = Elkhan Jafarov | producer = Mushfig Hatamov | writer = [[Agil Abbas]] | starring = [[Mammad Safa]]
[[Rza Rzayev]]
[[Elvin Ahmadov]] | music = [[Polad Bülbüloğlu]] | cinematography = Nadir Mehdiyev | editing = Elshad Rahimov | distributor = [[Azerbaijanfilm]] | released = {{Film date|df=y|2012|08|02|Azerbaijan}} | runtime = 84 min. | country = Azerbaijan | language = Azerbaijani | budget = $1.3 million{{cite web|title="Dolu" filminin büdcə qalmaqalı|url=http://publika.az/index.php?action=static_detail&static_id=14803|work=publika.az|accessdate=1 June 2013|language=Azerbaijani}} | gross = }} '''''Dolu''''' ({{lang-az|Dolu}}) is a 2012 Azerbaijani [[war film]] directed by [[Elkhan Jafarov]] based loosely on the [[Nagorno-Karabakh War]]. The film stars [[Mammad Shefa]], [[Rza Rzayev]] and [[Elvin Ahmadov]]. ==Background and structure== The film based on [[Agil Abbas]]'s novel, while initial stage of shootings took part in [[Ismayilli]].{{cite web|title=Shootings of "Dolu" film as the same name novel have begun|url=http://en.baku-art.com/index.php?newsid=3712#.UalCbUDrz-s|work=baku-art.az|accessdate=1 June 2013}}{{cite web|title=Azerbaijani film about Nagorno-Karabakh war to be released in Russia|url=http://vestnikkavkaza.net/news/culture/34527.html|work=vestnikkavkaza.ne|accessdate=1 June 2013}} ==Cast== * [[Mammad Safa]] as Commander * [[Rza Rzayev]] as Dragon * [[Elvin Ahmadov]] as Tiger * [[Shamil Suleimanli]] as Teacher * [[Farhad Israfilov]] as Police Officer * [[Rovshan Aghayev]] as Fighter of Azerbaijan * [[Javanshir Hadiyev]] as Fighter of Azerbaijan * [[Faig Karimoghlu]] as Fighter of Azerbaijan * [[Vugar Valikhanov]] as Fighter of Azerbaijan * [[Ogtay Guliyev]] as Base Manager * [[Shahmar Garibli]] as Chief Accountant * [[Sardar Isgandarov]] as Shelli Eldar ==See also== * [[Khojaly Massacre]] * [[Black January]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|3961690}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dolu, Film}} [[Category:2012 films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:2010s war films]] [[Category:Azerbaijani-language films]] [[Category:War drama films]] [[Category:Works about Khojaly Massacre]] [[Category:Azerbaijani films]] [[Category:Nagorno-Karabakh War films]] {{Azerbaijan-film-stub}} {{war-drama-film-stub}}

revision.text: {{Infobox airline | airline=Ecoair International | image= | caption= | IATA=9H | ICAO=DEI | callsign= | founded= | commenced=1999 | ceased=2002 | bases=[[Houari Boumedienne Airport]], Algeria | hubs= | fleet_size= | destinations=[[Brussels South Charleroi Airport]], Belgium | parent=Khalifa Group | headquarters=[[Algiers]], Algeria }} '''Ecoair International''' was an [[airline]] based in [[Algiers]], [[Algeria]], founded in 1999. In 2002 it was integrated into Khalifa Group, the parent company of [[Khalifa Airways]]. Operating out of [[Houari Boumedienne Airport]], Ecoair International provided flights to Europe, including [[Brussels South Charleroi Airport|Brussels-Charleroi]] and North Africa, and within Algeria. ==Code data== *[[International Air Transport Association|IATA]] Code: '''9H''' *[[International Civil Aviation Organization|ICAO]] Code: '''DEI''' ==History== Ecoair International was established in 1999 and started operations with the help of [[Khalifa Airways]] and the Khalifa Group.{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} ==See also== {{Portalbar|Algeria|Companies|Aviation}} ==External links== *'''Airline recorded as defunct in:''' [https://web.archive.org/web/20061004142454/http://www.airlinehistory.co.uk/Africa/Algeria/Airlines.htm Airline History, Algeria] [[Category:Defunct airlines of Algeria]] [[Category:Airlines established in 1999]] [[Category:Airlines disestablished in 2002]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Algeria]] [[Category:2002 disestablishments in Algeria]] {{Algeria-transport-stub}} {{Algeria-company-stub}} {{Africa-airline-stub}}

{{Infobox mountain |name = Eldgjá |photo = Eldgja.jpg |photo_caption = Canyon floor of Eldgjá |elevation = varies: canyon to {{Convert|800|m|ft|0}} |listing = [[List of volcanoes in Iceland]] |location = [[Iceland]] |map = Iceland |relief = 1 |map_caption = Location in Iceland |map_size = 200 |label_position = right |coordinates = {{coord|63|58|00|N|18|36|33|W|type:mountain_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} |type = [[Fissure vent]]s of [[Katla volcano|Katla]] |last_eruption = 939 }}
'''Eldgjá''' ({{IPA-is|ˈɛltcau|-|Is-Eldgjá pronunciation.ogg}}, "fire canyon") is a [[volcano]] and a [[canyon]] in [[Iceland]]. Eldgjá and the [[Katla volcano|Katla]] volcano are part of the same volcanic system in the south of the country.
Situated between [[Landmannalaugar]] and [[Kirkjubæjarklaustur]], Eldgjá is the largest volcanic canyon in the world, approx. 40 km long, 270 m deep and 600 m wide at its greatest.
==History== It was discovered by [[Þorvaldur Thoroddsen]] in 1893.
The first documented eruption in 939<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.volcanocafe.org/eldgja-eruption-dating | title=Eldgja: Eruption dating |date = 29 September 2016 | access-date=1 January 2017 | author=Albert Zijlstra}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Oppenheime|first1=Clive|last2=et al|title=The Eldgjá eruption: timing, long-range impacts and influence on the Christianisation of Iceland|journal=Climatic Change|date=19 March 2018|doi=10.1007/s10584-018-2171-9|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10584-018-2171-9|accessdate=19 March 2018}}</ref> was the largest [[flood basalt]] in historic time. The areal extent of the [[lava]] is around 800 km<sup>2</sup>.<ref>Árni Hjartarson 2011. Víðáttumestu hraun Íslands. (The Largest Lavas of Iceland). Náttúrufræðingurinn 81, 37-49.</ref> An estimated 18 km<sup>3</sup> of [[magma]] poured out of the earth.<ref name="gvp-history">{{Cite gvp|vn=372030|title=Katla: Eruptive History}}</ref> Evidence from [[Tree Rings|tree rings]] from around the [[Northern Hemisphere]] indicated that the eruption in 939 caused the summer of 940 to be one of the coolest summers in 1500 years. Summer average temperatures in places as disparate as [[Central Europe]], [[Scandinavia]], [[Canada]], [[Alaska]], and [[Central Asia]] were 2°C lower than normal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/03/180319090740.htm|title=Volcanic eruption influenced Iceland's conversion to Christianity|work=ScienceDaily|access-date=2018-03-30|language=en}}</ref>
In March 2018, a team of medieval historians and scientists from the [[University of Cambridge]] suggested that a famous medieval Icelandic poem, [[Völuspá|Vǫluspá]], estimated to date from 961, was a roughly contemporary chronicle of Eldgjá's eruption in 939.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://icelandmonitor.mbl.is/news/nature_and_travel/2018/03/19/10th_century_eldgja_eruption_thought_to_have_influe/|title=10th century Eldgjá eruption thought to have influenced Christianisation of Iceland|access-date=2018-03-30}}</ref> The researchers suggested that the dramatic imagery of Eldgjá's eruption was purposefully invoked in order to accelerate the [[Christianization of Iceland]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.express.co.uk/news/science/935196/iceland-volcano-eruption-news-eldgja-volcano|title=Iceland volcano ERUPTION: Scientists make shock discovery about Eldgja volcanic apocalypse|last=Kettley|first=Sebastian|date=2018-03-21|work=Express.co.uk|access-date=2018-03-30|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencealert.com/how-a-volcanic-outburst-1-000-years-ago-was-so-brutal-it-slayed-gods-ragnarok-norse-voluspa-eldgja|title=A Volcanic Explosion 1,000 Years Ago Was So Brutal, It Slayed Icelandic Gods|last=Dockrill|first=Peter|work=ScienceAlert|access-date=2018-03-30|language=en-gb}}</ref>
There is a waterfall named [[Ófærufoss]] within the canyon. A [[Natural arch|natural bridge]] across the waterfall vanished in 1993, reportedly due to excess water from melting ice.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://icelandreview.com/stuff/ask-ir/2007/08/28/can-you-tell-me-what-happened-natural-stone-bridge-over-ofaerufoss-eldgja|title=Can you tell me what happened to the natural stone bridge over Ófaerufoss at Eldgjá?|last=Review|first=Iceland|date=2007-08-28|work=Iceland Review|access-date=2018-03-30|language=en}}</ref>
The northern part of Eldgjá, including Ófærufoss, and surrounding areas, have been a part of [[Vatnajökull National Park]] since 2011.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ósnortin víðerni og einstakar jarðmyndanir|url=http://www.umhverfisraduneyti.is/frettir/nr/1858|publisher=Ministry for the Environment and Natural Resources|accessdate=24 March 2014|language=Icelandic|date=29 July 2011}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Geography of Iceland]] *[[Glacial lake outburst flood]] *[[Iceland hotspot]] *[[Iceland plume]] *[[List of glaciers of Iceland]] *[[List of lakes of Iceland]] *[[Timeline of volcanism on Earth]] *[[Volcanology of Iceland]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040603055052/http://volcano.und.nodak.edu/vwdocs/volc_images/europe_west_asia/eldgja.html Information on volcanism in the area] *[http://isafold.de/strutsstigur02/mg_ofaerufoss.htm Photos]

revision.text:
[[Image:Elmc logo.png|thumb|The European Law Moot Court Society]]{{Refimprove | date = February 2017 }}
The '''European Law Moot Court''' ('''ELMC''') is an annual [[moot court]] competition between rival teams of university students who have an interest in [[European Union law]].
The competition consists of a written round, regional finals, and an Europe-wide final. During the written round the teams of three or four students write two legal pleadings (one each for the applicant and respondent). From these written pleadings the teams are scored and the 48 highest scoring teams proceed to one of the four regional finals across the globe for oral hearings. One team from each regional final goes on to the all-European final where the four regional final winning teams argue before the judges of the [[European Court of Justice]] in [[Luxembourg]].
In addition, one member from each team at the regional finals can participate in the competition as the representative of the [[European Commission]] or [[Advocate-General]] of the European Court of Justice and is eligible to receive a separate award for his or her effort at the all-European finals. There is also a special award for the best oral speaker and the best written pleadings.
The motto of the competition is "moot, meet and compete".
== Participants ==
In the 2004/2005 competition, the regional finals were held in: *[[Madrid]], [[Spain]] *[[Gothenburg]], [[Sweden]] *[[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]] *[[New York City]], [[United States]]
In the 2005/2006 competition, the regional finals were held in: *[[Boston]], United States *[[Dublin]], [[Eire|Ireland]] *[[Ljubljana]], [[Slovenia]] *[[Bratislava]], [[Slovakia]]
In the 2006/2007 competition, the regional finals were held in: *[[Maastricht]], the [[Netherlands]] *[[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]] *[[Pécs]], [[Hungary]] *[[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]]
In the 2007/2008 competition, the regional finals were held in: *[[Dallas]], United States *[[Maribor]], Slovenia *[[Valencia, Spain|Valencia]], Spain *[[Bangor, Gwynedd|Bangor]], [[United Kingdom]]
In the 2010/2011 competition, the regional finals were held in: *[[Heidelberg]], [[Germany]] *[[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]] *[[Barcelona]], Spain *[[Dublin]], Ireland
In the 2011/2012 competition, the regional finals are held in: * [[Luxembourg City]], [[Luxembourg]] * [[Braga]], [[Portugal]] * [[Lucerne]], [[Switzerland]] * Istanbul, Turkey
==External links== *[http://www.europeanlawmootcourt.eu Official website of the European Law Moot Court]
{{International moot court competitions}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:European Law Moot Court Competition}} [[Category:Moot court competitions]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox companies |name = Hepco |native_name = |logo = |type = [[Public company|Public]] |slogan = |foundation = {{start date and age|1972}} |location = [[Arak, Iran]] |key_people = |industry = [[Heavy equipment]] ([[construction]] and [[mining]]) |products = *[[Construction equipment]] *[[Mining equipment]] *[[Industrial machinery]] |revenue = |net_income = |homepage = [http://www.hepcoir.com/ hepcoir.com] }}
{{About|the Iranian companies |the Japanese power company|Hokkaido Electric Power Company}} [[File:HEPCO HWL 110-2 wheel loaders (2).jpg|thumb|HEPCO wheel loaders]] '''Heavy Equipment Production Company''' ('''HEPCO''') is an [[Iran]]ian company producing road construction equipment in [[Iran]] and the [[Middle East]]. HEPCO has 1,500 employees with an annual production capacity of 4,800 units that is located in [[Arak, Iran|Arak]].<ref name=BYI/> HEPCO also assembles Japanese ''[[Komatsu Limited|Komatsu]]'' construction equipment.<ref name=BYI>{{Cite journal | last = Ayse | first = Valentine | url = http://www.investiniran.ir/en/filepool/26?redirectpage=%2fen%2febook | last2 = Nash | first2 = Jason John | author2-link = | last3 = Leland | first3 = Rice | title = The Business Year 2013: Iran | place = London, U.K. | publisher = The Business Year | date=January 2013 | page = 92 | isbn = 978-1-908180-11-7 | postscript =. }}</ref>
==History== HEPCO was established and registered in 1972, with the intention of assembly & production of road construction equipments.<ref name=BYI/> In 1975 HEPCO resumed operation in its premises in [[Arak, Iran|Arak]] consistory of 1000,000 square meters of land & 40,000 square meters of production hall in collaboration with licencors; namely : International Harvester, [[Dynapac]], [[Poclain]], Sakai & [[Lokomo]] .
In 1984, HEPCO development project was designed in collaboration with [[Liebherr Group|Liebherr]] & [[Volvo]] companies, aiming at fabrication of steel structures of road construction equipments.
The project recalled for construction of a 60,000 square meter hall and installation of numbers of modern cutting, welding and milling machines, capable of production 2100 units of equipments, in the first phase. In 1993, HEPCO Engineering & Parts was established, enabling HEPCO to produce more parts and component locally (other that steel structures).
As there was ample capacity in fabrication hall, from 1996 on the Company gradually engaged in fabrication of parts and components for industrial projects, as power stations, oil, gas and petrochemical complexes, portal cranes, etc. The capabilities thus gained, was later consolidated in a new Company in 2002 Energy Equipment Production Co. (Teta), fully owned by HEPCO. Today, HEPCO, together with its subsidiaries, and in collaboration with its world partners is active in production, supply and support of road construction mining and industrial projects.
Today HEPCO has close cooperation with companies Like: [[Volvo]], [[Komatsu Limited|Komatsu]], [[Liebherr Group|Liebherr]], [[New Holland Agriculture|Newholland]], [[XCMG]], [[Ingersoll Rand]], [[Case IH]], [[Deutz AG|Deutz]], Berco Carraro, [[Bosch Rexroth|Rexroth]] and Sauer.
==See also== *[[Automotive industry in Iran]] *[[Mining in Iran]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110501043805/http://hepcoir.com/ HEPCO Website] [http://www.pegatron168.com/]

{{convert|3860|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | length = {{convert|5712|mm|in|1|abbr=on}}
{{convert|6272|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|1950|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|2467|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|2634|-|2749|kg|lb|abbr=on}} | related = | designer = [[Karsan]] | sp = us }} The '''Karsan J10''' is a [[minibus]] produced by the [[Turkey|Turkish]] manufacturer [[Karsan]] from 2010 to 2015. ==Overview== It is the successor of the Karsan J9 Premier that was based on the platform of the 1980s' [[Peugeot J9]].{{cite web|title=Karsan J10: lointain Peugeot pour le Bosphore|url=http://www.leblogauto.com/2010/10/karsan-j10-lointain-peugeot-pour-le-bosphore.html|publisher=Le blog auto|date=16 October 2010}} It is available in three capacity versions, with 14, 17 or 20 seats, and is powered by a 2.3-liter [[common rail]] engine from [[Iveco]], developing {{convert|96|hp|kW||abbr=on}} and {{convert|240|Nm|lbft||abbr=on}}. Two length options are available, {{convert|3.3|m|ft|1}} or {{convert|3.8|m|ft|1}}, both with a [[Gross vehicle weight rating|GVWR]] between 4.1 and 4.3 tonnes. Standard equipment includes [[Anti-lock braking system|ABS]], [[Electronic brakeforce distribution|EBD]], automatic rear doors, [[sunroof]], electric windows, central locking and optional, air conditioning.{{cite web|title=Products - Passenger Transport - J10|url=http://en.karsan.com.tr/products/detail.aspx?SectionID=tsuxYY2rv8eFuGCZF1GypQ%3d%3d&ContentID=wkng0%2bpefrAma6WkR3uERg%3d%3d|publisher=Karsan|accessdate=25 January 2012}}{{cite web|title=J10 - Modeller - Yeni Karsan J10 Okul|url=http://www.karsanj10.com/modeller/default_servis_teknik_ozellikler.aspx|publisher=Karsan|accessdate=25 January 2012}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Buses}} *[http://www.karsanj10.com/default.aspx Official website] [[Category:Karsan vehicles|J10]] [[Category:Minibuses]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:2010s cars]] {{Turkey-stub}} {{Vehicle-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''National Library of the Republic of Mauritius''', has been entrusted by law as the national institution responsible for collecting, bibliographically recording, preserving and making available the nation’s [[collective memory]]. It provides information on practically all branches of knowledge and function as a center of coordination, planning and stimulation of the country’s [[library]] system. The institution was established by the Government under the National Library Act, 1996 (Act No. 32) as a [[body corporate]], under the Ministry of Arts and Culture. The National Library of the Republic of Mauritius was officially opened to the public in January 2000.
==Vision== The National Library of the Republic of Mauritius aims to be a top class library in the provision of [[information service]]s to the nation, thus contributing to its development.
==Mission statement== The National Library would provide equal access to information to all [[Mauritius|Mauritian]] nationals, thus leveling educational opportunities and deepening the [[democratization]] process. The objectives of the National Library are to promote and encourage the use of library materials; to acquire new library materials generally, and, in particular, materials relating to Mauritius; to lend library materials to the public; to participate in planning library services in Mauritius; to promote research in library fields and provide assistance in information handling techniques; to act as the national bibliographic center and maintain the national [[bibliography]]; to act as an organizing agency for national and international lending and exchange of library materials; and to initiate and promote cooperation between the library and other libraries, both at national and international levels.
==Role of the National Library of Mauritius== The main role of the National Library of Mauritius is to build a comprehensive collection of our national heritage by collecting, receiving and preserving all [[publication]]s and productions, printed and produced in Mauritius for present and future generations. The main source of acquisition is by means of the [[legal deposit]] system as per the National Library Act 1996 which stipulates that every printer in Mauritius is required to deposit, free of charge, with the Director of the National Library six copies of each publication, be it a book, periodical, report, newspaper or any other printed document. The same rule applies to all the producers in Mauritius who have to deposit six copies of any non-print materials produced. To ensure that access is given to the most comprehensive collection of [[Mauritiana]] materials, the National Library has to acquire all print and non-print materials published and printed abroad, whose subject matter is related to Mauritius. The National Library is also responsible to build a collection of foreign reference materials on different subjects of interest for the benefit of the Mauritian public at large. As an apex institution in the field of information in Mauritius, the National Library functions as a central institution for coordination, planning and development of the entire [[library system]] of Mauritius.
==Holdings== The National Library’s Mauritius collection consists of materials in various formats such as: written or graphic records, typescripts, books, newspapers, periodicals, music scores, photographs, maps, drawings, and non-print materials such as films, filmstrips, audiovisual items including tapes, discs and reproductions relating to any subject and produced in Mauritius or relating to Mauritius and produced overseas. The Library's holdings totaled 510,000 as of 2014-15.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cdnl.info/sites/default/files/docs/reports/2015_Annual_Report_Mauritius_2014_15.pdf|title=National Library (Republic of Mauritius), Annual Report to CDNL 2014-15|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 12, 2018}}</ref> Subject coverage includes: [[agriculture]], [[architecture]], [[biography]], [[computer science]], [[economics]], [[geography]], [[handicraft]], [[history]], [[language]]s, [[literature]], [[politics]], pure and applied sciences, [[religion]] and so on. Our holdings also comprise rare documents namely bluebooks, almanacs, administrative reports, National Assembly debates, manuscripts, theses/dissertations, government gazettes, newspapers, and other documents dating back to 1777.
==External links== *[http://national-library.govmu.org/English/Pages/default.aspx Official site]
{{Africa topic|title=African national libraries|prefix=National Library of}}
[[Category:1996 establishments in Mauritius]] [[Category:Mauritian culture]] [[Category:National libraries|Mauritius]] [[Category:Libraries established in 1996]] [[Category:Deposit libraries]]

revision.text:
[[File:Secretary Kerry Speaks With National Foundation Division of Antarctic Sciences Director Scott Borg, Inside a hut Where Explorer Ernest Shackleton and 14 Other men Lived in 1908 (30913580755).jpg|thumb|Scott Borg (''left'') with [[John Kerry]] in Antarctica in 2015]] '''Scott G. Borg''' is an American [[geologist]] and civil servant. Since 1 September 2017 he has been the Deputy Assistant Director of the Directorate for Geosciences at the United States' [[National Science Foundation]] (NSF). <ref>{{cite web |title=Borg appointed temporary Geosciences assistant director |url=https://www.nsf.gov/news/news_summ.jsp?cntn_id=243081&org=OPP |website=National Science Foundation |publisher=US National Science Foundation |accessdate=1 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Staff Directory, Directorate for Geosciences (GEO/OAD) |url=https://www.nsf.gov/staff/staff_list.jsp?org=GEO&from_org=GEO |website=National Science Foundation |publisher=US National Science Foundation |accessdate=1 October 2018}}</ref> ==Education== Borg graduated from [[Pomona College]] with a B.A. in [[geology]], and earned M.S. and Ph.D. degrees from [[Arizona State University]], where his doctoral dissertation was titled ''[[Granitoid]]s of Northern Victoria Land, Antarctica (Tectonics, Neodymium-isotopes, Geochemistry, Petrology, Strontium-isotopes)''.<ref name="uvm"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Borg, Scott 1984|url=https://search.lib.asu.edu/primo-explore/fulldisplay?docid=TN_proquest303321950&context=PC&vid=01ASU&lang=en_US&search_scope=Everything&adaptor=primo_central_multiple_fe&tab=default_tab&query=any,contains,Scott%20Borg&sortby=rank&facet=rtype,include,dissertations&offset=0|website=lib.asu.edu|publisher=[[Arizona State University]]|accessdate=March 3, 2018}}</ref>
==Career== He began his career as a researcher at the [[University of California, Berkeley|University of California at Berkeley]].<ref name="uvm">{{cite web|title=Biographical Sketch Scott G. Borg|url=https://www.uvm.edu/~epscor/pdfFiles/2008_Annual_Meeting/Borg_Scott.pdf|website=uvm.edu|publisher=[[University of Vermont]]|accessdate=March 3, 2018}}</ref> He later worked for the [[United States Department of Energy]], and subsequently joined the staff of the National Science Foundation.<ref name="uvm"/><ref name="wfed"/> Between 2003 and 2016 he was director of the Division of Antarctic Sciences at the National Science Foundation <ref name="wfed">{{cite news|last1=Somers|first1=Meredith|title=Scott Borg: Passion for science, education not cooling anytime soon|url=https://federalnewsradio.com/public-service-recognition-week/2016/04/scott-borg-passion-science-education-not-cooling-anytime-soon/|accessdate=March 3, 2018|work=[[WFED]]|date=April 29, 2016}}</ref>, and in 2016-17 he served as the acting Section Head for Antarctic Infrastructure and Logistics (AIL) within the National Science Foundation Division of Polar Programs. <ref name="uvm"/><ref name="ses">{{cite web|title=Senior Executive Service Presidential Rank Awards 2015|url=https://www.opm.gov/policy-data-oversight/senior-executive-service/presidential-rank-awards/2015/agency/national-science-foundation/|website=[[Office of Personnel Management]]|publisher=[[United States Government]]|accessdate=October 1, 2018}}</ref> In 2017, he began serving as associate director for geosciences at the National Science Foundation. <ref name="uvm"/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Mervis|first1=Jeffrey|title=Departing senior NSF manager offers hopeful assessment of agency’s future|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/02/departing-senior-nsf-manager-offers-hopeful-assessment-agency-s-future|accessdate=March 3, 2018|work=[[Science Magazine]]|date=February 27, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Steering Committee on Agency Reform |url=https://www.nsf.gov/oirm/bocomm/meetings/spring_2017/SCAR_Member_Bios_for_BOAC.pdf |website=National Science Foundation |publisher=US National Science Foundation |accessdate=1 October 2018}}</ref>
==Research expeditions== Borg has participated in a total of six research expeditions to Antarctica, four of which he has led.<ref name="uvm"/> During a 1978–1979 expedition in which he participated, the [[Sagehen Nunataks]] were first visited, receiving their name from the [[Pomona Sagehens]], athletic moniker of Borg's alma mater Pomona College.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sagehen Nunataks|url=https://data.aad.gov.au/aadc/gaz/display_name.cfm?gaz_id=131119|website=Australian Antarctic Data Centre|publisher=[[Commonwealth of Australia]]|accessdate=March 4, 2018}}</ref> During the same expedition, Borg named [[Tongue Peak]], choosing the name from a tongue-shaped [[moraine]] on the peak.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tongue Peak|url=https://data.aad.gov.au/aadc/gaz/display_name.cfm?gaz_id=132773|website=Australian Antarctic Data Centre|publisher=[[Commonwealth of Australia]]|accessdate=March 4, 2018}}</ref>
==Awards and honors== In 1994, [[Borg Bastion]], the summit on [[Johns Hopkins Ridge]], was named in his honor.<ref>{{cite web|title=GNIS - Antarctica Detail|url=https://geonames.usgs.gov/apex/f?p=gnispq:5:0::NO::P5_ANTAR_ID:1681|website=[[U.S. Geological Survey]]|publisher=[[United States Government]]|accessdate=March 3, 2018}}</ref> Borg has received the [[Samuel J. Heyman Service to America Medals|Samuel J. Heyman Medal]] from the [[Partnership for Public Service]] and been decorated with the [[Presidential Rank Award of Distinguished Executive]].<ref name="ses"/><ref name="cr">{{cite journal|title=Recognizing the Contributions and Career Achievements of Dr. Scott Gerald Borg|journal=[[Congressional Record]]|date=2014|volume=160|issue=137|url=https://www.congress.gov/congressional-record/2014/11/12/extensions-of-remarks-section/article/E1547-2}}</ref> In 2014, [[United States Representative]] [[Gerald Connolly]] read a statement of recognition into the ''[[Congressional Record]]'' in which he credited Borg with overseeing "the development of clean drilling technology that retrieved the first-ever pure water samples from an Antarctic lake a half mile below the surface of ice sheet ... [which] may enable researchers to understand what types of life can survive on other worlds".<ref name="cr"/>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Borg, Scott G.}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Pomona College alumni]] [[Category:Arizona State University alumni]] [[Category:American geologists]] [[Category:Presidential Rank Award recipients]] [[Category:Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:American civil servants]] [[Category:United States National Science Foundation officials]]

revision.text:
{{For|the inhabitants of the United States|Stereotypes of African Americans}} {{copy edit|date=October 2018}} {{globalize/US|date=October 2018}} Stereotypes and generalizations about [[Africa|Africans]] and their [[Culture of Africa|culture]] have evolved within the [[Western world]] since the years of colonial settlement, particularly after slavery became a heritable racial institution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/africa-stereotype-article-1.1197466|title=The Africa Stereotype|website=Nydailynews.com|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/travel/africa-beyond-the-stereotypes-73190999/|title=Africa: Beyond the Stereotypes|website=Smithsonianmag.com|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fmag.unict.it/Public/Uploads/links/Stereotypes%20and%20prejudice%20toward%20Africans%20in%20univ%20students.pdf |format=PDF |title=WCPCG 2013 : The relationship between stereotypes and prejudice toward the Africans in Italian university students |author1=Rossella Falanga |author2=Maria Elvira De Carolia |author3=Elisabetta Sagone |website=Fmag.uniict.it |accessdate=2017-05-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=myLOFYZ4dQ0C&pg=PA98&dq=Stereotypes+of+Africans&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjWsaf2h_XTAhWpC8AKHc-8BtQQ6AEISTAH#v=onepage&q=Stereotypes+of+Africans&f=false|title=Perspectives on Africa: A Reader in Culture, History and Representation|first1=Roy Richard|last1=Grinker|first2=Stephen C.|last2=Lubkemann|first3=Christopher|last3=Steiner|date=17 May 2010|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|accessdate=16 May 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xSqIrrswbG0C&pg=PA485&dq=Stereotypes+of+Africans&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjWsaf2h_XTAhWpC8AKHc-8BtQQ6AEIKDAB#v=onepage&q=Stereotypes+of+Africans&f=false|title=African Sexualities: A Reader|first=Sylvia|last=Tamale|date=23 June 2011|publisher=Fahamu/Pambazuka|accessdate=16 May 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> ==Common stereotypes==
===One country===
One of the common misperceptions of Africa is that it is a single country as opposed to [[List of sovereign states and dependent territories in Africa|54 countries]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/118600/america-must-stop-stereotyping-africa-continent-animals|title=Americans Think Africa Is One Big Wild Animal Reserve|website=Newrepublic.com|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/02/07/world/africa/africa-is-not-a-country-campaign/index.html|title='Africa is not a country': Campaign dispels stereotypes|first=Teo Kermeliotis, for|last=CNN|website=CNN|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/nov/28/africans-worry-how-africa-portrayed-western-media |title=Why Africans worry about how Africa is portrayed in western media | Remi Adekoya | Opinion |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date= |accessdate=2017-05-23}}</ref>
==== One language ==== Similarly, many believe Africans speak 'African' and that 'African' is an actual language. In reality, African as a language does not exist; over 2000 [[Languages of Africa|distinct languages]] are currently spoken throughout the continent.<ref name=":0" />
===Backwardness=== [[File:Lagos.png|thumb|[[Lagos]] is a city in [[Nigeria]]. With a population of 21 million,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2012/07/this-is-africas-new-biggest-city-lagos-nigeria-population-21-million/259611/|title=This Is Africa's New Biggest City: Lagos, Nigeria, Population 21 Million|last=Campbell|first=John|date=10 July 2012|website=[[The Atlantic]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=19 October 2018}}</ref> it is the largest city in Africa.|alt=5 photos of buildings in the city of Lagos, Nigeria. With a population of 21 million, it is the largest city in Africa.|265x265px]] ==== Poverty ==== A common misconception is that the continent is the epicentre of a primitive culture and poverty.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/mar/08/stereotyping-of-africans-is-everywhere-but-australians-are-particularly-clueless|title=Stereotyping of Africans is everywhere, but Australians are particularly clueless|date=7 March 2016|website=Theguardian.com|accessdate=16 May 2017|via=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/business/tech/2017-02/09/content_28144901.htm|title=Young Africans embrace Chinese gadgets, shatter stereotypes - Business |website=Chinadaily.com.cn|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ebony.com/news-views/africa-by-the-africans-034#axzz4hGgdHalT|title=AFRICA BY THE AFRICANS: Young Tastemakers Aim to Challenge Stereotypes - EBONY|website=Ebony.com|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://newafricanmagazine.com/erasing-stereotypes-africa/|title=Erasing stereotypes about Africa - New African Magazine|date=13 January 2015|website=Newafricanmagazine.com|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://voicesofafrica.co.za/dispelling-stereotypes-about-africans/|title=Dispelling stereotypes about Africans - Voices of Africa|date=3 February 2014|website=Voicesofafrica.co.za|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/fighting-stereotypes-with-stories/a-36433960|title=Fighting stereotypes with stories - Africa - DW.COM - 18.11.2016|website=DW.COM|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref> While a number of countries in Africa are indeed poor, many countries in Africa have thriving and prosperous economies, including [[Economy of South Africa|South Africa]], [[Economy of Nigeria|Nigeria]], and [[Economy of Kenya|Kenya]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bremmem |first1=Nur |title=7 African countries with booming ecommerce markets |url=http://ventureburn.com/2014/12/7-african-countries-booming-ecommerce-markets/ |website=Ventureburn |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref>
==== Technology ==== Africans are often perceived as having "no access to modern technology" but this is inaccurate.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.globalcitizen.org/en/content/africans-are-all-poor-and-15-other-myths/|title=15 Reasons African Countries Aren't 'Shitholes'|last=Kelland|first=Zoe|last2=Sanchez|first2=Erica|date=12 January 2018|website=Global Citizen|publisher=Global Poverty Project|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=19 October 2018}}</ref> In fact, 80% of Africans could access a [[mobile phone]] in 2013. [[Internet in Africa|Internet usage across Africa]] has also grown by 20% in 2018, with penetration rates across [[North Africa]] of 59%, [[West Africa]] of 39%, and [[Southern Africa]] of 51%<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.africanews.com/2018/02/06/digital-in-2018-africa-s-internet-users-increase-by-20-percent//|title=Digital in 2018: Africa's internet users increase by 20% {{!}} Africanews|last=AfricaNews|work=Africanews|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en}}</ref> ==== Urbanisation ==== Many people falsely believe that all Africans live in "mud house[s] in the middle of nowhere".<ref name=":0" /> In reality, 43% of the continent's population dwells in urban areas.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.statista.com/statistics/270860/urbanization-by-continent/|title=Urbanization in 2018, by continent|last=|first=|date=|website=Statista.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=19 October 2018}}</ref> ===Crime=== ====Fraud====
A common [[Stereotypes of Nigerians|stereotype]] is that [[Nigerians]] commit [[Internet fraud|online fraud]]. The most well-known Nigerian scam is the [[Advance-fee scam]].
===Wildlife===
Another mistaken belief about Africa is that [[Fauna of Africa|wild animals]] are commonplace. While there are many large wild animals (such as lions) in Africa, many citizens of African countries typically don't see these types of animals outside of zoos.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.socialstudies.org/publications/ssyl/march-april2008/beyond_wildlife_teaching_about_africa_and_stereotypes|title=Beyond Wildlife: Teaching about Africa and Stereotypes|date=12 April 2016|website=Socialstudies.org|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref>
{{Africa-stub}}

{{Infobox Network |network_name = Televisão Pública de Angola |network_logo = [[File:Televisão Pública de Angola.jpg|200px]] |country = {{flagcountry|Angola}} |founded = {{Start date and age|1973|06|27}} |network_type = [[Terrestrial television|Broadcast]] |available = National | |owner = [[Government of Angola]] |website = [http://tpa.sapo.ao/ tpa.sapo.ao] | }} '''Televisão Pública de Angola E.P.''' or '''TPA''' is the national broadcaster of the Southern [[Africa|African]] state of [[Angola]]. It also operates an international channel '''TPA Internacional'''. TPA is headquartered in the capital city [[Luanda]] and broadcasts in [[Portuguese language]]. The international channel broadcasts selected shows targeted at foreign audiences and the Angolan community abroad. TPA1 is currently the only state-owned broadcaster in Angola following the arrival of private channels [[TV Zimbo]] and [[Palanca TV]] and the privatization of TPA2. {{Infobox TV channel| name=TPA 1| logofile=| logosize=| launch=| slogan= Somos Todos Nós
''It Is All Of Us''| picture format=[[aspect ratio (image)#4:3 standard|4:3]]| country= {{flag|Angola}} | language=[[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]| owner= [[Government of Angola]] | web= [http://www.tpa.ao]| broadcast area= '''[[Angola]]'''
'''[[South Africa]]'''
'''[[Europe]]'''
'''[[Africa]]'''| sat serv 1= [[Intelsat|Intelsat 906]] (Africa, Europe)| sat chan 1=| sat serv 2= [[NSS 7]] (South Africa)| sat chan 2= | sat serv 3= [[DStv]] ([[Sub-Sahara Africa]])| sat chan 3= Channel 570| sat serv 4= [[ZAP (satellite television)|ZAP]] ([[Angola]])| sat chan 4= Channel 1| |}} {{Infobox TV channel| name=TPA Internacional| logofile=| logosize=| launch=| slogan=| picture format=[[aspect ratio (image)#4:3 standard|4:3]]| country= {{flagcountry|Angola}} | language=Portuguese| owner= [[Government of Angola]] | web= [http://www.tpa.ao]| broadcast area= '''Europe'''
'''[[Middle East]]'''
'''[[North Africa]]'''
'''[[North America]]'''
'''[[South America]]'''| sat serv 1= [[Eutelsat|Eutelsat W3A]] (Europe, Middle East, North Africa)| sat chan 1= 11345 H 27500-2/3| sat serv 2= [[Telstar|Telstar 12]] (North & South America)| sat chan 2= 11963 H 14714-3/4| sat serv 4 = ZAP Moçambique ([[Mozambique]]) | sat chan 4 = 4 | cable serv 1=TV Cabo ([[Mozambique]])| cable chan 1= 4| cable serv 2= [[ZON Multimédia|NOS]] ([[Portugal]])| cable chan 2= 191| iptv serv 1 = [[Meo (Portugal)|MEO]] ([[Portugal]])| iptv chan 1 = 230| |}} ==History== Prior to TPA's establishment, there were some experiments made in colonial-era Angola: the first was made in 1962, from Rádio Clube do Huambo. On January 8, 1964, Rádio Clube de Benguela made the second experiment, and then, on June 22, 1970, Luanda tested television for the first time. Televisão Pública de Angola was founded on June 27, 1973 as '''Radiotelevisão Portuguesa de Angola''' from [[Government of Portugal|Portuguese government]] authorities.http://www.tpa.ao/artigo.aspx?sid=eb8eb85a-e984-4b92-9324-22f35e2f9475&cntx=LGs9L0SGj6h3fLc9epT1tXZgIp3%2BbMhOKXTneaEaxyA%3D{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} The first television signal launched on October 18, 1975 in [[Luanda]]. Less than a year after the official launch and the country's independence, the company changed its name for the first time to '''Televisão Popular de Angola''', on June 25, 1976. In 1979, TPA began to look into expansion, starting with [[Benguela]], then in 1981 in [[Huambo]]. It was in Huambo that the first regional production centre was established. In 1982, TPA started producing programming in native languages, with the first two being [[Malanje]] and [[N'dalatando|N'Dalatando]]. Currently the so-called "national languages" have a special focus on the news, of which a dedicated block exists on the main channel. Colour television arrived to Angola in 1983. In 1992, TPA expanded to the whole of the country thanks to [[Satellite television|satellite connections]]. In 1997, TPA became a [[public company]] and the official name changed to '''Televisão Pública de Angola'''. In 2000 TPA 2 started [[broadcasting]]. Broadcasts did not become official for another two years. In 2003, TPA's channels started broadcasting through the [[Ku band|KU band]], launching the channels on the international [[DStv]] platform. On 31 January 2007, TPA began broadcasting 24 hours a day.{{cite web |url=http://www.portalangop.co.ao/angola/pt_pt/noticias/sociedade/2007/0/5/TPA-comeca-emitir-horas-partir-hoje,286fda96-fc73-4dff-89f7-d4f6fa873df7.html |title=TPA começa a emitir 24/24 horas a partir de hoje |publisher=ANGOP.com |date= 31 Jan 2007 |accessdate= 4 Dec 2014|language=pt}} On 24 July 2008 the international channel was launched and became available in Portugal's main cable and [[IPTV]] platforms. ==Channels== *TPA 1 - the main channel *TPA Internacional - for foreign audiences ==Programming== TPA 1: {{col-begin|width=900px}} {{col-break|}} ===Information=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; |- |África Hoje || Wed || 13:30-14:00 |- |Bom Dia Angola || Mon-Fri || 06:00-09:30 |- |Ecos e Factos || Mon-Fri || 18:00-19:00 |- |Jornal da Noite || Mon-Fri || 00:00-00:30 |- |Línguas Nacionais || Mon-Fri || 09:30-10:00 |- |Telejornal || Mon-Fri || 20:00-21:00 |} {{col-break|}} ===Sports=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; |- |1º de Agosto || Sat || 11:45-12:00 |- |Desporto Total || Thu || 21:00-23:00 |- |Diário Desportivo || Mon-Fri || 12:30-13:00 |- |Domingo Desportivo || Sun || 15:30-17:30

'''The Madcaps''' was an [[Austria]]n band that was founded in 1965 in [[Strasshof]] by [[Hans Kloiber]].
The most successful songs were ''I man i dram'', ''Schneemensch'', and ''Und wem's net gfoid, der soll sich haun über d'Häusa''. [[Georg Danzer]], one of the members who wrote some of their songs, later started a solo career.

{{Primary sources|date=April 2009}} '''Union of Translators of [[Russia]]''' ('''UTR''') is a professional union of the translators, interpreters, teachers of [[translation]] and specialists in different genres and spheres of [[translation]] and [[interpreting]].
UTR branches work in many regions of Russia ([[Astrakhan]], [[Vladivostok]], [[Volgograd]], [[Voronezh]], [[Ekaterinburg]], [[Nizhni Tagil]], [[Ivanovo]], [[Irkutsk]], [[Kazan]], [[Kaliningrad]], [[Kaluga]], [[Krasnodar]], [[Novorossisk]], [[Sochi]], [[Moscow]], [[Moscow Region]], [[Nizhni Novgorod]], [[Novosibirsk]], [[Orenburg]], [[Perm]], [[Ryazan]], [[Rostov-on-Don]], [[Samara, Russia|Samara]], [[St. Petersburg]], [[Saransk]], [[Saratov]], [[Smolensk]], [[Stavropol]], [[Tomsk]], [[Tula (Russia)]], [[Ulyanovsk]], [[Ufa]], [[Khabarovsk]], [[Chita, Zabaykalsky Krai|Chita]], [[Yakutsk]]). UTR is a member of [[International Federation of Translators]] (FIT).
== External links == * [http://www.translators-union.ru/ Official site of the Union of Translators of Russia] * [http://www.utr-ural.ru/ Official site of Sverdlovsk Region Branch of the Union of Translators of Russia] * [http://utr.spb.ru/ Official site of Saint-Petersburg Branch of the Union of Translators of Russia] * [http://lang.mrsu.ru/ Official site of Mordovian Branch of the Union of Translators of Russia, [[Saransk]]]

[[Image:Viasat.png|right|200px]] [[File:Viasat old logo.svg|right|200px]] '''Viasat Ukraine''' is a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] [[direct broadcast satellite]] television distributor. It is owned by "Vision TV" which is a joint venture between the Strong Media Group (SMG) and the Swedish [[Modern Times Group]] (MTG). It competes with [[NTV Plus|NTV Plus Ukraine]] and [[Poverkhnost]] which broadcast on the [[Eutelsat]] system.
The service was launched April 21, 2008 <ref>{{cite press release|url=http://php.mtg.se/observer/news.php?action=news&action_id=5&news_id=164162|title=MTG Launches Viasat Ukraine Satellite Pay-TV Platform|date=April 16, 2008|publisher=MTG}}</ref> using [[DVB-S]] & [[DVB-S2]] transponders on the [[Sirius (satellite)#Sirius 4|Astra 4A]], [[Hot Bird]] and [[AMOS (satellite)|AMOS]] satellites to broadcast channels compressed with [[MPEG-2]] & [[MPEG-4 AVC]] codecs.

{{other uses}} {{Multiple issues| {{original research|date=August 2015}} {{lead too short|date=August 2012}} }} {{Expand German|West-Berlin|date=November 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox former country |native_name = ''West-Berlin
''Berlin-Ouest
''Berlin (West)'' |conventional_long_name = West Berlin |common_name = West Berlin |religion = [[Christianity]] ([[Evangelical Church in Germany|Evangelical]], [[Catholic Church|Catholic]]), [[Islam]], [[Judaism]] |nation = Berlin |status = [[Allied-occupied Germany|Western Allies-occupied sectors of Berlin]] |era = Cold War |year_start = 1949 |date_start = 12 May |event_start = End of the [[Berlin Blockade]] |year_end = 1990 |date_end = 3 October |event_end= [[German reunification|Reunification]] |official_languages = [[German language|German]] | languages = [[Berlinerisch dialect|Berlinerisch]] |p1 = Allied-occupied Germany |flag_p1 = Flag of Germany (1946-1949).svg |s1 = Germany |flag_s1 = Flag of Germany.svg |s2 = Berlin |flag_s2 = Flag of Berlin.svg |image_flag = Flag_of_Berlin.svg |image_coat =Coat of arms of Berlin.svg |image_map = West & East Berlin (1945-1990).png |image_map_caption = The four occupation sectors of Berlin. West Berlin is in light blue, dark blue, and purple, with several [[West Berlin#Exclaves|exclaves]] shown. Borough borders are as of 1987. |title_leader = [[Governing Mayor of Berlin#Partitioned Germany (1948–1990)|Governing Mayor]] |leader1 = [[Ernst Reuter]] ([[Social Democratic Party of Germany|SPD]]) |leader2 = [[Walter Momper]] (SPD) |year_leader1 = 1948–1953 ''(first)'' |year_leader2 = 1989–1990 ''(last)'' |stat_area1 = |stat_year1 = |stat_pop1 = |footnotes = |today={{flag|Germany}} }} {{History of Berlin}} '''West Berlin''' ({{lang-de|Berlin (West)}} or colloquially ''West-Berlin'') was a political [[enclave]] which comprised the western part of [[Berlin]] during the years of the [[Cold War]]. There was no specific date on which the sectors of Berlin occupied by the [[Western Bloc|Western Allies]] became "West Berlin", but 1949 is widely accepted as the year in which the name was adopted. West Berlin aligned itself politically with [[West Germany|the Federal Republic of Germany]] (also known as the "Bonn Republic") and was directly or indirectly represented in its federal institutions. West Berlin was formally controlled by the Western Allies and was entirely surrounded by the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]]-controlled [[East Berlin]] and [[East Germany]]. West Berlin had great symbolic significance during the Cold War, as it was widely considered by westerners as an "island of [[free world|freedom]]". It was heavily subsidised by West Germany as a "showcase of the West".Tobias Hochscherf, Christoph Laucht, Andrew Plowman, ''Divided, But Not Disconnected: German Experiences of the Cold War'', p. 109, Berghahn Books, 2013, {{ISBN|9781782381006}} A wealthy city, West Berlin was noted for its distinctly cosmopolitan character, and as a centre of education, research and culture. With about two million inhabitants, West Berlin had the largest population of any city in Germany during the Cold War era.[https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/11/07/berlin-where-rivalry-of-east-west-soars "Berlin: Where Rivalry of East, West Soars"], ''[[US News and World Report]]'', 18 July 1983 West Berlin was {{convert|100|mi|km|0|abbr=off}} east and north of the [[Inner German border]] and only accessible by land from West Germany by narrow rail and highway corridors. It consisted of the American, British, and French occupation sectors established in 1945. The [[Berlin Wall]], built in 1961, physically separated West Berlin from its East Berlin and East German surroundings until it [[Fall of the Berlin Wall|fell]] in 1989.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/august/13/newsid_3054000/3054060.stm "1961: Berliners wake to divided city"], [[BBC News]] ==Origins== [[File:Wberlin transport 78.jpg|thumb|West Berlin, as of 1978]] [[File:West and East Berlin.svg|thumb|
Map of West and East Berlin, border crossings, metro networks
{{nowrap|([[ShareMap:public/West and East Berlin|interactive map]])}}]] The [[Potsdam Agreement]] established the legal framework for the occupation of Germany in the wake of World War II. According to this agreement, Germany would be formally under the administration of the three major wartime [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] (the United States, the United Kingdom, and the [[Soviet Union]]) as well as France until a German government "acceptable to all parties" could be established. The territory of Germany, as it existed in 1937, would be reduced by most of ''Eastern Germany'' thus creating the [[Former eastern territories of Germany#Post World War II|former eastern territories of Germany]]. The remaining territory would be divided into four zones, each administered by one of the four allied countries. Berlin, which was surrounded by the [[Soviet Zone of occupation in Germany|Soviet zone of occupation]]—newly established in most of [[Middle Germany]]—would be similarly divided, with the Western Allies occupying an enclave consisting of the western parts of the city. According to the agreement, the occupation of Berlin could end only as a result of a [[wikt:quadripartite|quadripartite]] agreement. The Western Allies were guaranteed three air corridors to their sectors of Berlin, and the Soviets also informally allowed road and rail access between West Berlin and the western parts of Germany (see section on traffic).{{citation needed|reason=|date=August 2015}} At first, this arrangement was intended to be of a temporary administrative nature, with all parties declaring that Germany and Berlin would soon be reunited. However, as the relations between the Western Allies and the Soviet Union soured and the Cold War began, the joint administration of Germany and Berlin broke down. Soon, Soviet-occupied Berlin and western-occupied Berlin had separate city administrations.{{cite book|last=Ladd|first=Brian|title=The Ghosts of Berlin: Confronting German History in the Urban Landscape|date=1997|pages=178–179|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago|isbn=978-0226467627}} In 1948, the Soviets tried to force the Western Allies out of Berlin by imposing a land blockade on the western sectors—the [[Berlin Blockade]]. The West responded by using its [[West Berlin Air Corridor|air corridors]] for supplying their part of the city with food and other goods through the [[Berlin Airlift]]. In May 1949, the Soviets lifted the blockade, and West Berlin as a separate city with its own jurisdiction was maintained. Following the Berlin Blockade, normal contacts between East and West Berlin resumed. This was temporary until talks were resumed. In 1952, the East German government began sealing its borders, further isolating West Berlin.{{cite magazine |last=Attwood |first=William |editor-last=Cowles |editor-first=Gardner |title=Berlin calmly rides out its Pinprick War |department=European Affairs, Look Reports |magazine=LOOK |language=English |location=Des Moines, Iowa |publisher= Cowles Magazines, Incorporated|publication-date=15 July 1952 |volume=16 |issue=15 |page=90}} As a direct result, electrical grids were separated and phone lines were cut. The [[Volkspolizei]] and Soviet military personnel also continued the process of blocking all the roads leading away from the city, resulting in several armed standoffs and at least one skirmish with the [[National Gendarmerie|French Gendarmerie]] and the [[Bundesgrenzschutz]] that June. However, the culmination of the schism did not occur until 1961 with the construction of the [[Berlin Wall]]. ==Legal status== From the legal theory followed by the Western Allies, the occupation of most of Germany ended in 1949 with the establishment of the Federal Republic of Germany (23 May 1949) and of the German Democratic Republic (7 October 1949). Under Article 127 of the [[Basic Law for the Federal Republic of Germany|Basic Law]] (or constitution) of the Federal Republic, provision was made for federal laws to be extended to Greater Berlin (as West Berlin was officially known) as well as [[Baden]], [[Rhineland-Palatinate]] and [[Württemberg-Hohenzollern]] within one year of its promulgation.[https://www.bundestag.de/blob/284870/ce0d03414872b427e57fccb703634dcd/basic_law-data.pdf Article 127 [Extension of law to the French zone and to Berlin] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304075359/https://www.bundestag.de/blob/284870/ce0d03414872b427e57fccb703634dcd/basic_law-data.pdf |date=4 March 2016 }} Within one year after the promulgation of this Basic Law the Federal Government, with the consent of the governments of the Länder concerned, may extend to the Länder of Baden, Greater Berlin, Rhineland-Palatinate and Württemberg-Hohenzollern any law of the Administration of the Combined Economic Area, insofar as it remains in force as federal law under Article 124 or 125.] However, because the occupation of Berlin could only be ended by a quadripartite agreement, Berlin remained an occupied territory under the formal sovereignty of the allies. Hence, the Basic Law was not fully applicable to West Berlin.[https://books.google.com/books?id=oWFzvKt8fVoC&pg=PA89&lpg=PA89&dq=constitution+berlin+1950&source=bl&ots=hyuCIJgkpd&sig=6M92IDToC3d9dPMZ0Z_d5ugtsuc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiLgOHypbbKAhWGtxQKHaDVD3MQ6AEITDAL#v=onepage&q=constitution%20berlin%201950&f=true ''The Constitution of the Federal Republic of Germany''], David P. Currie University of Chicago Press, 1994, page 89 On 4 August 1950 the [[House of Representatives of Berlin|House of Representatives]] (the city's legislature) passed a new constitution, declaring Berlin to be a state of the Federal Republic and the provisions of the Basic Law as binding law superior to Berlin state law (Article 1, clauses 2 and 3). However, this became statutory law only on 1 September and only with the inclusion of the western Allied provisionCf. Berlin [[Allied Kommandatura|Kommandatura]] Ordinance BK/O (50) 75, 29 August 1950, clause 2b, published in the then Berlin legal gazette VOBl. I, p. 440. according to which Art. 1, clauses 2 and 3, were deferred for the time being; the clauses became valid law only on 3 October 1990 (the day of Germany's unification). It stated that:
Article 87 is interpreted as meaning that during the transitional period Berlin shall possess none of the attributes of a twelfth Land. The provision of this Article concerning the Basic Law will only apply to the extent necessary to prevent a conflict between this Law and the Berlin Constitution...[https://books.google.com/books?id=N6DFsKBss-wC&pg=PA44&lpg=PA44&dq=Die+Bestimmungen+dieses+Artikels+(87)+betreffend+das+Basic+Law,+finden+nur+in+dem+Ma%C3%9Fe+Anwendung,+als+es+zwecks+Vorbeugung+eines+Konflikts+zwischen+diesem+Gesetz+und+der+Berliner+Verfassung+erforderlich+ist&source=bl&ots=iQqWEbHUY3&sig=GydD0ZsmDVxQ0EJQHE1GSYhrn98&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjgqZvwu7bKAhXDuBQKHRKyA-wQ6AEIIjAA#v=onepage&q=Die%20Bestimmungen%20dieses%20Artikels%20(87)%20betreffend%20das%20Basic%20Law%2C%20finden%20nur%20in%20dem%20Ma%C3%9Fe%20Anwendung%2C%20als%20es%20zwecks%20Vorbeugung%20eines%20Konflikts%20zwischen%20diesem%20Gesetz%20und%20der%20Berliner%20Verfassung%20erforderlich%20ist&f=false ''Das richterliche Prüfungsrecht in Berlin''], Peter Hauck Duncker & Humblot, 1969, page 44In the German translation the respective clause of the Kommandatura Ordinance reads as follows: "Die Bestimmungen dieses Artikels (87) betreffend das Basic Law, finden nur in dem Maße Anwendung, als es zwecks Vorbeugung eines Konflikts zwischen diesem Gesetz und der Berliner Verfassung erforderlich ist". Cf. Decision of the [[Constitutional Court of Germany|Constitutional Court of the Federal Republic of Germany]] [http://opinioiuris.de/entscheidung/764 ''BVerfG, 25.10.1951 - 1 BvR 24/51'' (Der Grundrechtsteil des Bonner Basic Lawes gilt auch in West-Berlin.)], on: [http://opinioiuris.de/ ''OpinioIuris: Die freie juristische Bibliothek''], retrieved on 2 May 2012.
Thus civic liberties and personal rights (except for the privacy of telecommunications) guaranteed by the Basic Law were also valid in West Berlin. In addition, West German federal statutes could only take effect in West Berlin with the approval of the city's legislature. The ambiguous legal status of the city, then still legally styled as Greater Berlin (although technically only comprising the western sectors), meant that West Berliners were not eligible to vote in federal elections. In their notification of permission of 12 May 1949 the three western military governors for Germany explained their proviso in No. 4, as follows:
A third reservation concerns the participation of Greater Berlin in the Federation. We interpret the effect of Articles 23 and 144 (2) of the Basic Law as constituting acceptance of our previous request that while Berlin may not be accorded voting membership in the Bundestag or Bundesrat nor be governed by the Federation she may, nevertheless, designate a small number of representatives to the meetings of those legislative bodies.[http://usa.usembassy.de/etexts/ga4-490512.htm ''Approval by Western Military Governors''], on [http://usa.usembassy.de/ U.S. Diplomatic Mission to Germany], retrieved on 2 May 2012.
Consequently, West Berliners were indirectly represented in the [[Bundestag]] in [[Bonn]] by 22 non-voting delegates[https://books.google.com/books?id=F54jJBcrs50C&pg=PA34&lpg=PA34&dq=bundestag+west+berlin+22&source=bl&ots=fHvcgFedJi&sig=TOHuagAFxKdwr04qEslLTYLQzyM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjQxITa37PKAhUC1hQKHddqCikQ6AEIOTAF#v=onepage&q=bundestag%20west%20berlin%2022&f=true ''Germany at the Polls: The Bundestag Elections of the 1980s''], Karl H. Cerny, Duke University Press, 1990, page 34 chosen by the House of Representatives.[http://www.ipu.org/parline-e/reports/arc/GERMANY_FEDERAL_REPUBLIC_1980.PDF GERMANY (FEDERAL REPUBLIC OF) Date of Elections: 5 October 1980], [[International Parliamentary Union]] Similarly, the [[Senate of Berlin|Senate]] (the city's executive) sent four non-voting delegates to the [[Bundesrat (Germany)|Bundesrat]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZGbfBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA3&lpg=PA3&dq=bundesrat+west+berlin&source=bl&ots=6F09K0wr5v&sig=8CyWHFI1bbFhtK_o2YZR962zV_M&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiloZSi3rPKAhUEvhQKHY7PBEgQ6AEIQDAF#v=onepage&q=bundesrat%20west%20berlin&f=false ''West Germany Today (RLE: German Politics)''], Karl Koch, Routledge, 1989, page 3 In addition, when the [[European Parliament election, 1979|first direct elections]] to the [[European Parliament]] were held in 1979, West Berlin's three members were instead indirectly elected by the House of Representatives.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=BTrjAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Bundestag%22+%22West+Berlin%22+%22House+of+Representatives%22&dq=%22Bundestag%22+%22West+Berlin%22+%22House+of+Representatives%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjSnouOnNTeAhWrrVQKHbrpDIcQ6AEINDAC ''The Bulletin''], Issues 1-3, 1979, page 6 However, as [[#Citizenship|West German citizens]], West Berliners were able to stand for election in West Germany. For example, Social Democrat [[Willy Brandt]], who eventually became Chancellor, was elected via his party's list of candidates. It should be noted that the West German government considered all West Berliners as well as all citizens of the GDR to be citizens of West Germany. Also, male residents of West Berlin were exempt from the Federal Republic's compulsory military service; this exemption made the city a popular destination for West German young people, which resulted in a flourishing [[counterculture]], which in turn became one of the defining features of the city.[https://books.google.com/books?id=RjY4AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA166&lpg=PA166&dq=military+service+%22west+berlin%22&source=bl&ots=IGeH7y4dGs&sig=d5tFMsf12M0kJ9038y89RHBrRf0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjSsdyRibfKAhXLvhQKHXVMAmcQ6AEIUjAL#v=onepage&q=military%20service%20%22west%20berlin%22&f=true ''Avant-Garde Film: Motion Studies''], Scott MacDonald, CUP Archive, 1993, page 166[http://www.dw.com/en/tracing-west-berlins-70s-and-80s-subculture/a-16615845 Tracing West Berlin's 70s and 80s subculture], [[Deutsche Welle]], 21 February 2013 [[File:Berlin Alert 0400.jpg|thumb|left|In 1969 U.S. military vehicles pass through the residential district of [[Zehlendorf (Berlin)|Zehlendorf]], a routine reminder that West Berlin was still legally occupied by the Western Allies of World War II]] The Western Allies remained the ultimate political authorities in West Berlin. All legislation of the House of Representatives, whether of the West Berlin legislature or adopted federal law, only applied under the proviso of confirmation by the three Western Allied commanders-in-chief. If they approved a bill, it was enacted as part of West Berlin's statutory law. If the commanders-in-chief rejected a bill, it did not become law in West Berlin; this, for example, was the case with West German laws on military duty. West Berlin was run by the elected [[Governing Mayor of Berlin|Governing Mayor]] and Senate seated at [[Rathaus Schöneberg]]. The Governing Mayor and Senators (ministers) had to be approved by the Western Allies and thus derived their authority from the occupying forces, not from their electoral mandate. The Soviets unilaterally declared the occupation of East Berlin at an end along with the rest of East Germany. This move was, however, not recognised by the Western Allies, who continued to view all of Berlin as a jointly occupied territory belonging to neither of the two countries. This view was supported by the continued practice of patrols of all four sectors by soldiers of all four occupying powers. Thus, occasionally Western Allied soldiers were on patrol in East Berlin as were Soviet soldiers in West Berlin. After the Wall was built, East Germany wanted to control Western Allied patrols upon entering or leaving East Berlin, a practice that the Western Allies regarded as unacceptable. So, after protests to the Soviets, the patrols continued uncontrolled on both sides, with the tacit agreement that the western Allies would not use their patrolling privileges for helping Easterners to flee to the West. In many ways, West Berlin functioned as the ''de facto'' 11th [[states of Germany|state]] of West Germany, and was depicted on maps published in the West as being a part of West Germany. There was freedom of movement (to the extent allowed by geography) between West Berlin and West Germany. There were no separate immigration regulations for West Berlin, all immigration rules for West Germany being followed in West Berlin. West German entry [[Visa (document)|visas]] issued to visitors were stamped with "for the Federal Republic of Germany, including Land Berlin", in German "''für die Bundesrepublik Deutschland einschl. [einschließlich] des Landes Berlin''", prompting complaints from the Soviet Union. However, this wording remained on the visas throughout the rest of the entire period of West Berlin's existence.[https://books.google.com/books?id=CMibQNH4U4IC&lpg=PA100&vq=valid%20for%20entry&pg=PA100#v=snippet&q=valid%20for%20entry&f=false ''Bridge Builder: An Insider's Account of Over Sixty Years in Post-war Reconstruction, International Diplomacy, and German-American Relations''], Walther Leisler Kiep Purdue University Press, 2012, page 100[http://www.worldpassportstamps.com/germany-transit-visa-1991/ ''Germany – transit visa, 1991 (issued 24 July 1990)''], World of Passport Stamps West Berlin remained under military occupation until 3 October 1990, the day of [[German reunification|unification]] of East Germany, East and West Berlin with [[West Germany|Federal Republic of Germany]]. The West German Federal Government, as well as the governments of most western nations, considered East Berlin to be a "separate entity" from East Germany, and while the Western Allies later opened embassies in East Berlin, they recognised the city only as the ''seat of government'' of the GDR, not as its ''capital''.[https://books.google.com/books?id=DhuQAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA158&dq=Embassy+of+the+French+Republic+in+Berlin+gdr&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiJ0bKp2bjKAhXM2xoKHSq8AywQ6AEIcjAQ#v=onepage&q=Embassy%20of%20the%20French%20Republic%20in%20Berlin%20gdr&f=false ''Architecture, Politics, and Identity in Divided Berlin''], Emily Pugh, University of Pittsburgh Press, 2014, pages 158-159 Communist countries, however, did not recognise West Berlin as part of West Germany and usually described it as a "third" German jurisdiction, called in German ''selbständige politische Einheit'' ("independent political unit").[https://books.google.com/books?id=vzmNb84n7sUC&pg=PA183&lpg=PA183&dq=West+Berlin+special+political+area&source=bl&ots=OBy00qbYpg&sig=vLbh048ZkEnC4mRtnepDCkZUVtg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiVvp3zobbKAhUIaxQKHXWfDPQQ6AEIbTAR#v=onepage&q=West%20Berlin%20special%20political%20area&f=true ''The East German Leadership, 1946-73: Conflict and Crisis''], Peter Grieder, Manchester University Press, 1999, page 183 On maps of East Berlin, West Berlin often did not appear as an adjacent urban area but as a monochrome terra incognita, sometimes showing the letters WB, meaning West Berlin, or overlaid with a legend or pictures.
